us_news:
• Federal Reserve Holds Interest Rates Steady: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged and signaled that it now anticipates only one rate cut in 2024, down from a previous projection of three, citing a need for greater confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2%.
  • Hunter Biden Convicted on All Counts: A federal jury found Hunter Biden, son of President Joe Biden, guilty on all three felony charges related to illegally purchasing a firearm in 2018 while he was a user of crack cocaine, marking the first time a sitting president's child has been criminally convicted.
  • Inflation Cools in May CPI Report: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for May showed that inflation unexpectedly cooled, with prices remaining flat from the previous month and rising 3.3% annually, providing a positive sign for the economy ahead of the Fed's policy decision.
  • House Votes to Hold AG Garland in Contempt: The U.S. House of Representatives voted to hold Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress for his refusal to turn over audio recordings of President Biden's interview with special counsel Robert Hur.
  • Joey Chestnut Banned from Nathan's Hot Dog Contest: In a major upset for competitive eating fans, 16-time champion Joey Chestnut has been banned from participating in the 2024 Nathan's Famous Fourth of July hot dog eating contest due to a sponsorship deal with a rival plant-based food brand.
  • Southern Baptists Narrowly Reject Ban on Female Pastors: Delegates at the Southern Baptist Convention's annual meeting narrowly voted down a proposed constitutional amendment that would have banned churches with any women serving in pastoral roles, a significant outcome in a contentious debate over gender and church leadership.
  • US and Ukraine to Sign 10-Year Security Pact: The United States and Ukraine are set to sign a 10-year bilateral security agreement at the G7 summit, committing Washington to long-term support, training, and intelligence sharing to bolster Ukraine's defense against Russia.
  • Pro-Palestinian Protesters Vandalize NYC Homes of Museum Leaders: The homes of the director and several Jewish board members of the Brooklyn Museum were vandalized with red paint and threatening pro-Palestinian messages, prompting condemnation from city officials and a police hate crimes investigation.
  • Jerry West, NBA Legend and Logo Inspiration, Dies at 86: Jerry West, the legendary Los Angeles Lakers player and executive whose silhouette is the basis for the NBA's logo, has passed away at the age of 86. He was a champion, an MVP, and a revered figure throughout the basketball world.
  • Florida Braces for 'Life-Threatening' Flooding: South Florida is under a state of emergency as a tropical disturbance brings torrential rainfall, causing widespread flash flooding that has submerged streets, stalled vehicles, and led to numerous water rescues across several counties.
financial_news:
• U.S. Market Close: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite set new record highs, largely driven by a surge in tech stocks, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average ended slightly lower. Investor focus is squarely on upcoming inflation data and the Federal Reserve's policy decision.
  • Apple Hits All-Time High: Apple (AAPL) stock soared over 7% to a record high as investors reacted positively to the company's new 'Apple Intelligence' AI features announced at its developer conference, making it a primary driver of the day's market gains.
  • Fed Meeting Underway: The Federal Reserve began its two-day monetary policy meeting. While no change in interest rates is expected, the market is anxiously awaiting Wednesday's statement, economic projections (the 'dot plot'), and Chair Jerome Powell's press conference for clues on future rate cuts.
  • Inflation Data on Deck: Markets exhibited caution ahead of the crucial Consumer Price Index (CPI) report for May, due to be released Wednesday morning. The inflation data is expected to heavily influence the Fed's tone and market direction.
  • Crypto Market Slides: Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies saw a significant sell-off, with Bitcoin's price falling below $67,000. The decline is attributed to market-wide anxiety ahead of the U.S. CPI report and the Fed's interest rate decision.
  • Oracle Surges on AI Deals: Oracle (ORCL) shares jumped in after-hours trading following its earnings report. The company announced major cloud infrastructure deals with Google and OpenAI, overshadowing a miss on quarterly revenue and boosting investor sentiment on its AI strategy.
  • Treasury Yields Dip: U.S. Treasury yields fell as investors moved into the safety of government bonds before the key economic releases. The yield on the 10-year note dropped, signaling investor demand for less risky assets amid uncertainty.
  • European Stocks Falter on Political Fears: European markets closed lower, with French stocks leading the decline. Political uncertainty in France, following President Macron's call for a snap election, has raised concerns about the country's fiscal stability.
  • World Bank Global Outlook: The World Bank slightly upgraded its 2024 global growth forecast to 2.6%, citing strong U.S. economic performance. However, it warned that overall global output will remain well below pre-pandemic levels and highlighted risks from conflict and trade barriers.
  • Oil Prices Edge Higher: Crude oil prices posted modest gains, supported by OPEC's monthly report which maintained its forecast for relatively strong growth in global oil demand in 2024.
conspiracies:
• Theory: Following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, theories are spreading that the incident was an intentional act or a cyberattack, despite officials stating it appears to be an accident caused by the cargo ship losing power.
  • Theory: Speculation continues around Kate Middleton, with new theories suggesting her recent appearance at a farm shop was with a professional body double, fueled by minor facial discrepancies noted by social media users.
  • Theory: Following federal raids on Sean 'Diddy' Combs' properties, social media is rife with theories connecting him to a wider network of powerful individuals, with users analyzing old videos and interviews for 'clues' about his alleged activities.
  • Theory: The 'Boeing Whistleblower' theory is trending again, with users speculating about the recent death of a second whistleblower, Joshua Dean. This is being linked to the earlier death of John Barnett, with many claiming foul play is involved to silence critics of the company's safety standards.
  • Theory: A viral topic claims that the popular fast-fashion retailer Temu is malware or spyware. Users are sharing videos alleging the app requests unnecessary permissions to access extensive data on users' phones beyond what is needed for shopping.
  • Theory: The 'Quiet Sabotage' or 'Malicious Compliance' work trend is being discussed, where employees intentionally do the bare minimum or strictly adhere to rules to the point of inefficiency as a form of protest against their employers, rather than 'quiet quitting'.
  • Theory: Following Candace Owens' departure from The Daily Wire, theories are circulating that she was fired due to pressure from influential pro-Israel donors and lobbyist groups over her commentary on the Israel-Hamas conflict.
  • Theory: A conspiracy is circulating that recent solar flares and geomagnetic storms are not natural phenomena but are being caused by a secret government weather or energy weapon, often linked to programs like HAARP.
  • Theory: The 'Great Reset' conspiracy has resurfaced, with viral posts claiming recent global events, like supply chain issues and inflation, are being deliberately orchestrated by a global elite to dismantle capitalism and enforce a new world order.
  • Theory: A viral discussion revolves around the concept of 'Seed Oil Disrespectors,' a theory that the widespread use of processed seed oils (like canola, soy, and sunflower oil) in modern diets is a primary driver of chronic inflammation and various diseases.
